etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Transactions of the Linnean Society of London. From post-classical Latin reiectamenta, plural of reiectamentum

definitions: Seaweed, debris, etc., washed up by the sea or by tides or floodwaters.
Things rejected as useless, worthless, or superfluous; refuse, detritus.
Material excreted, regurgitated, or otherwise discarded by an animal during or after feeding.
